div.head: Report:
div.p: The purpose of the experiments was to study the properties of the interface between Mnpthalocyanine (Mn-Pc) molecules and ferromagnetic Co(100). In particular, we wanted to:

1. Confirm the ferromagnetic coupling we observed previously between Mn in Mn-Pc and Co; 2. Check if there is a sizeable XMCD signal at the N K edge of the Mn-Pc molecules due to the interaction with the Co(100); 3. Check if the Mn-Pc molecules modify the properties of the underlying Co layer.

All samples were prepared in the ID8 prepration chamber equiped with a scanning tunneling microscope (STM). We deposited 1 ML of Mn-Pc molecules either on a Cu(100) single crystal or on various thicknesses of epitaxial Co/Cu(100). We obtained molecular resolution with the STM, and were thus able to prove the quality of the MnPc layer and crosscheck the thickness calibration (cf. fig 1). We select in the following two samples as a summary to show that we could address the 3 points mentionned above. As reference layer, we measured the hysteresis loop of 0.9 ML Co/Cu(100) using the intensity of the XMCD at the Co L3 edge (fig. 2). The magnetic properties are those expected for a film with such a thickness in this sytem. At room temperature the film is (super)paramagnetic. At 8 K, the film is ferromagnetic with an magnetic easy axis in plane. By applying the sum rules, we find m L = 0.2 µ B and m S =1.50 µ B . Next we added 1 ML Mn-Pc on top of this sample to obtain 1ML MnPc/0.9 ML Co/Cu(100).

The hysteresis loop on Co is qualitatively the same as the one obtained on the uncovered sample (fig. 3). The easy magnetization axis is still in-plane. Interestingly, the hysteresis loop on Mn is similar to the loop obtained on Co, which confirm the magnetic coupling between Mn in Mn-Pc and the underlaying Co layer (fig. 3). As there are much less Mn atoms than Co atoms, the loop on Mn is noisier, with an opening for the loop measured at 70° that is probably an artefact. By applying the sum rules on the Co XMCD, we find m L = 0.2 µ B and m S =1.43 µ B . This small reduction of the Co spin moment might be within error bars and has to be confirmed.

This result nevertheless shows that adsorption of Pc molecules have a minor impact on the Co surface magnetization, in agreement with our DFT calculations. Similar measurements have been performed incresing Co thickness. As we confirmed that the Mn is coupled to the Co, we tried to check if it's possible to measure an XMCD signal at the N K edge. The hope was to confirm experimentally what we proved based on theoretical calculations in an article to appear : the polarization of N due to the underlaying Co is of main importance in spintronics in these systems. The XMCD signal can be seen on fig. 4. Due to the presence of harmonics, we had to substract the Co XMCD occuring around 397 eV. The residual signal is very small and a more detailed analysis is under progress, also taking into account measurements on different samples, before this feature can be attributed definitively to the XMCD at the N K edge.
